name: Metropolitan Ervin Szabó Library
description: A 19th-century artistocrat's mansion, turned into a library, hidden in a modern library. While it can be a confusing process to find the Central Library in the maze-like modern section of the library, once you do, all that is left is to pick out a beautiful old book, sink back into a deep leather chair, surrounded by the soft light of chandeliers, and relax like a 19th-century Hungarian aristocrat.

name: Vajdahunyad Castle
description: This Hungarian castle was built out of cardboard and wood until it proved so popular that it got upgraded to stone. Also hosts the Budapest Agricultural Museum where a  fake Transylvanian castle houses a cathedral of antlers.

name: Museum of Applied Arts
description: tWHS - Ödön Lechner's independent pre-modern architecture

name: Szent László Church
description: tWHS - Ödön Lechner's independent pre-modern architecture

name: Buda Castle Funicular
description: Built in 1870 at the bridge that connected Buda and Pest, this spectacular incline railway was almost lost forever during World War II.

name: Andrássy út
description: WHS

description: tWHS - Caves of the Buda Thermal Karst System

description: tWHS - Caves of the Buda Thermal Karst System

description: tWHS - Caves of the Buda Thermal Karst System

name: Buda Castle
description: WHS

name: Hungarian Parliament Building
description: WHS

name: Thermae Maiores
description: Legions of Roman soldiers bathed in this ancient spa complex under a Budapest transit station.

name: Ministry of Agriculture
description: bullet holes in arcade

name: Zugliget Chairlift
description: A two-way chairlift system between Zugliget and the highest point in the city.

name: Mansfeld Peter Memorial
description: This statue of a falling man commemorates a teenage martyr of the Hungarian Revolution.

name: Hospital in the Rock
description: A museum dedicated to a secret military hospital hidden beneath a castle in Budapest.

name: Szimpla Kert
description: A Trabant car, a kangaroo statue, and a plethora of plants take over this abandoned-factory-turned-bar.

name: Memento Park
description: Budapest's Communist-era statues, banished to the suburbs.

name: Semmelweis Museum
description: A museum in the childhood house of a medical pioneer.

name: Epreskert
description: The romantic garden was the epicenter of the Hungarian art scene in the 1880s.

name: Zwack Unicum Museum
description: Central Europe's largest collection of mini-bottles is on display at this museum devoted to a bitter Hungarian liquor.

name: Hungarian Electrotechnical Museum
description: Electrical curiosity museum housed in an old transformer station.

name: Michael Jackson Memorial Tree
description: A random tree outside a Budapest hotel has become a DIY shrine to the late singer.

name: Párisi Udvar
description:
a fine example of
Eclectic architecture popular in the
late 19th century and drawing on a
multitude of earlier styles. Originally
part of a bank building, the arcade has
recently been restored.

name: St. Stephen's Basilica
description: home to the Holy Right - The mummified right fist of a 1,000-year-old saint-king sits inside an ornate golden reliquary.

name: Rosenstein Vendéglő
description: Dine on Hungarian-Jewish dishes at this multigenerational, family-run institution

name: Urania National Film Theater
description: A stunning Art Nouveau cinema in the heart of Budapest.

name: Ghetto Memorial Wall
description: The holes in this wall provide a glimpse into Jewish life in Budapest, both past and present.

name: Carl Lutz Memorial
description: This sculpture honors the man who was known as the "Righteous Among the Nations."

name: Memorial for Victims of the German Occupation
description: A highly-criticized monument in Budapest has become the site of a makeshift Holocaust memorial.

name: Statue of Imre Nagy
description: A much-loved sculpture depicting the hero of a 1956 anti-Soviet uprising

name: The Policeman
description: Also known as Uncle Karl, the beloved bronze copper keeps a watchful eye on St. Stephen’s Basilica while people rub his lucky belly.

name: Gömböc-szobor
description: The largest statue of this convex, homogeneous object with just one stable and one unstable equilibrium point.

name: For Sale Pub
description: This Budapest bar allows drinkers to leave their mark on the walls, floor, and even ceiling.

name: Centrál Grand Cafe & Bar
description: Some of the greatest minds in the history of Hungarian art and science converged in this café.

name: Shoes on the Danube Bank
description: A trail of iron footwear stands as a monument to the thousands executed along this riverbank during WWII.

name: Citadella-kilátópont
description: From Austrians to Nazis to Soviets, this historic Budapest fortress has a history as complex as the city itself.

name: Gellért Hill Cave
description: Once the home of a hermetic monk, this cave now houses a small church.

name: Hűvösvölgy, Children's Railway
description: This quaint Hungarian railway system is operated exclusively by children between the ages of 10 and 14.

name: Garden of Philosophers
description: Tucked away near more famous landmarks lies a statue meant to symbolize the confluence and continuing development of human culture. In a secret corner of Budapest's Gellért Hill, the world's greatest religious figures meet silently around an orb. At least, that's what Hungarian sculptor Nándor Wagner envisioned when he created "The Garden of Philosophy," a cluster of statues you may happen upon if you wander away from the major tourist attractions of the Citadel and the Liberty Statue, perched atop the crown of the popular hill overlooking the Danube.

name: Mining and Geological Survey of Hungary
description: This hidden art nouveau gem was designed by an architect in search of a national style.

name: Postal Savings Bank
description: tWHS - Ödön Lechner's independent pre-modern architecture

name: The Church of Our Lady of Buda Castle
description: The towers of Matthias Church stand as integral landmarks within the Castle District. Yet many locals and tourists alike have never ventured inside the building (see recent photos here). The church, in line with tradition, was consecrated by order of St Stephen, though its construction took place during the reign of Béla IV in the 13th century. Despite undergoing reconstruction, renovations, and damage by the war, the church endures, though only fragments of its original features remain. The building exudes a uniquely special and almost mystical atmosphere, with its walls adorned with rich decorations. The tower offers one of the most stunning views of the city, provided you're willing to climb the 200 steps up to the top.

name: MOL Campus
description: Controversial and divisive, the MOL Campus, Budapest’s first skyscraper, has introduced a new colour and style to the city at the end of 2022. This architectural addition has reshaped the city's skyline while pushing the boundaries in terms of technical innovation. In April, its lookout point also opened, allowing visitors to take in panoramic views from a height of 120 meters. Anticipate unconventional yet breathtaking vistas, which are worth a visit whether you find the building itself captivating or polarizing. While the visitor's centre can be entered free of charge, a ticket is required to access the SkyDeck terrace

name: Vigadó Concert Hall
description: Built in 1865 based on the plans of Frigyes Feszl, the Vigadó is perhaps the last reminder of the pre-World War II ambience of the Danube Promenade. The famous Danube-side hotels burned for three days after the bombing of the city during World War II, and the Vigadó was severely damaged. It was only restored decades later, in the 1980s. As well as the exciting programmes, social events, and the beauty of the building, it is worth taking in the spectacular views from the windows and roof terrace. It's easy to sneak into the building for exhibitions and programmes, but it's worth a stroll to discover its secrets.

name: Buja Disznó(k) Buda - A RÁNTOTTHÚS és egyéb disznóságok!
